questions.sentence_with_blank: We go to the park ___ weekend.
questions.full_sentence: We go to the park every weekend.
questions.explanation: Use "every" to show frequency.

prompt.text: ___ time I see her, she is happy.

questions.sentence_with_blank: ___ time I see her, she is happy.
questions.full_sentence: Every time I see her, she is happy.
questions.explanation: Use "Every time" as a conjunction meaning whenever.

prompt.text: I have read ___ book in the library.

questions.sentence_with_blank: I have read ___ book in the library.
questions.full_sentence: I have read every book in the library.
questions.explanation: Use "every" to indicate completion of a set.

definition.en: To begin to be; to grow or come to be.
definition.ar: البدء في أن يكون؛ النمو أو الوصول إلى حالة معينة.

words.usage_notes: Irregular verb: become, became, become.

examples.ar: أصبح الجو بارداً جداً في الليل.

questions.explanation: "become" is the base verb for a change in state.
The Arabic verb "يصبح" translates to "become".

questions.full_sentence: I hope to become a pilot.
questions.explanation: Use the base form "become" after "to".

questions.full_sentence: He became a father last year.
questions.explanation: Use "became" for the past tense of "become".
Use "becoming" for a gradual change in the present.

prompt.text: She ___ quiet when she is sad.

questions.sentence_with_blank: She ___ quiet when she is sad.
questions.full_sentence: She becomes quiet when she is sad.
questions.explanation: Use "becomes" for third-person singular present.
Use "become" as the past participle after "have".
Use the base form "become" after "will".

definition.en: In the space separating two objects or regions.
definition.ar: في المساحة التي تفصل بين كائنين أو منطقتين.

words.usage_notes: Usually used for two distinct items.

examples.en: The ball is {between} the two boxes.
I am sitting {between} Ahmed and Ali.
The shop is {between} the bank and the pharmacy.

questions.explanation: "between" indicates a position in the middle of two things.
The Arabic "بين" translates to "between" in English.

prompt.text: The letter B is ___ A and C.

questions.sentence_with_blank: The letter B is ___ A and C.
questions.full_sentence: The letter B is between A and C.
questions.explanation: Use "between" to show position in a sequence of two.

prompt.text: I can't decide ___ the red or blue one.

questions.sentence_with_blank: I can't decide ___ the red or blue one.
questions.full_sentence: I can't decide between the red or blue one.
questions.explanation: Use "between" when choosing from two options.

prompt.text: The cat is hiding ___ the chairs.

questions.sentence_with_blank: The cat is hiding ___ the chairs.
questions.full_sentence: The cat is hiding between the chairs.
questions.explanation: Use "between" for space separating two objects.
Use "between" to show a time range.

prompt.text: There is a fence ___ the two houses.

questions.sentence_with_blank: There is a fence ___ the two houses.
questions.full_sentence: There is a fence between the two houses.
questions.explanation: Use "between" to show separation.

questions.full_sentence: Keep this between you and me.
questions.explanation: Common phrase meaning to keep a secret.

definition.en: To take place; to occur.
definition.ar: أن يقع؛ أن يحدث.

words.usage_notes: Commonly used to ask about events or situations.

examples.en: It {happens} to the best of us.
I don't want this to {happen} again.
examples.ar: لا أريد أن يحدث هذا مرة أخرى.

questions.explanation: "happen" is the base verb for an event taking place.
The Arabic verb "يحدث" translates to "happen".
Use "happened" for a past event.
Use "happens" for third-person singular present.

questions.full_sentence: I wonder what will happen next.
questions.explanation: Use the base form "happen" after "will".

prompt.text: A lot is ___ in the world right now.

questions.sentence_with_blank: A lot is ___ in the world right now.
questions.full_sentence: A lot is happening in the world right now.
questions.explanation: Use "happening" for the present continuous.
Use the base form "happen" after "did".

prompt.text: I don't want it to ___ again.

questions.sentence_with_blank: I don't want it to ___ again.
questions.full_sentence: I don't want it to happen again.
questions.explanation: Use the base form "happen" after "to".

definition.en: A group of people related by blood or marriage.
definition.ar: مجموعة من الأشخاص تربطهم صلة الدم أو الزواج.

words.usage_notes: Can be used as a noun or an adjective (e.g., family car).

examples.ar: تعيش العديد من العائلات في هذا المبنى.

questions.explanation: "family" refers to a group of related people.
The Arabic "عائلة" translates to "family" in English.

questions.full_sentence: He has a very large family.

Use "families" for more than one group.
Use "family" as an adjective to describe the photo.

prompt.text: I spend time with my ___ on weekends.

questions.full_sentence: They are like family to me.

Use "Family" as an adjective at the start of the sentence.

definition.en: Extending directly upward from; or across a space.
definition.ar: يمتد مباشرة إلى الأعلى من؛ أو عبر مساحة.

words.usage_notes: Can be a preposition, adverb, or adjective.

questions.explanation: "over" can mean above something or that something is finished.
The Arabic "فوق" or "عبر" translates to "over".
Use "over" to show movement across the top of something.

questions.full_sentence: School is over for the summer.
questions.explanation: Use "over" to mean finished.
Use "over" to mean "more than".

questions.full_sentence: Put the blanket over the bed.
questions.explanation: Use "over" to mean covering something.
Use "over" to show falling across something.

prompt.text: The plane is flying ___ the city.

questions.sentence_with_blank: The plane is flying ___ the city.
questions.full_sentence: The plane is flying over the city.
questions.explanation: Use "over" to mean above.

definition.en: Having lived for a long time; or made long ago.
definition.ar: عاش لفترة طويلة؛ أو صُنع منذ زمن بعيد.

words.usage_notes: Used for both people (age) and objects (time since creation).

examples.en: This is the {oldest} house in town.

questions.explanation: "old" is used for age or long-existing things.
The Arabic "قديم" translates to "old" in English.
Use "old" after years to state age.

questions.full_sentence: She is older than her sister.
questions.explanation: Use "older" to compare the age of two people.

questions.full_sentence: This is a very old building.
questions.explanation: Use "old" to describe something made long ago.

prompt.text: He is the ___ man in the village.

questions.sentence_with_blank: He is the ___ man in the village.
questions.full_sentence: He is the oldest man in the village.

Use "old" to describe a car that is not new.

questions.full_sentence: The old ways are sometimes best.

definition.en: Used to give an affirmative response.
definition.ar: يستخدم لإعطاء رد إيجابي.

words.usage_notes: The standard affirmative answer in English.

questions.explanation: "yes" is the standard affirmative response.
The Arabic "نعم" translates to "yes" in English.

questions.full_sentence: Yes, I would love some tea.
questions.explanation: Use "Yes" to accept an offer.
Use "Yes" to answer a question affirmatively.
Use "Yes" to confirm a statement.
Use "yes" as the opposite of "no".
Use "Yes" to agree to a request.

questions.full_sentence: Is it raining? - Yes, it is.
questions.explanation: Use "Yes" to confirm a current state.

definition.en: Another time; once more.
definition.ar: مرة أخرى؛ من جديد.

words.usage_notes: Used to indicate the repetition of an action or state.

examples.ar: من فضلك قل ذلك مرة أخرى.

examples.en: I am happy to see you {again}.

questions.explanation: "again" means one more time.
The Arabic "مرة أخرى" translates to "again" in English.
Use "again" to ask for a repetition.

prompt.text: I failed, but I will try ___ .

questions.sentence_with_blank: I failed, but I will try ___ .
questions.full_sentence: I failed, but I will try again.
questions.explanation: Use "again" to show a repeated attempt.
Common phrase used when meeting someone for the second time.
Use "again" to warn against repeating an action.
Use "again" to show that an event occurred once more.

definition.en: A person who is studying at a school or college.
definition.ar: شخص يدرس في مدرسة أو كلية.

words.usage_notes: Used for anyone engaged in learning at an institution.

questions.explanation: "student" is a person who learns at a school.

questions.sentence_with_blank: The ___ are quiet during the test.
questions.full_sentence: The students are quiet during the test.
questions.explanation: Use "students" for a plural group of learners.

questions.sentence_with_blank: I was a ___ ten years ago.

questions.sentence_with_blank: She is the best ___ in the school.

questions.explanation: Use "student" to refer to a single learner.
Use "student" to ask about someone's educational status.

definition.en: To such a great extent; or for that reason.
definition.ar: إلى حد كبير؛ أو لهذا السبب.

words.usage_notes: Can be used as an adverb of degree or a conjunction.

examples.en: It was raining, {so} I stayed home.

examples.en: He was {so} tired that he fell asleep.

questions.explanation: "so" can mean "very" or "therefore".
The Arabic "لذلك" translates to "so" in English.
Use "so" as an adverb of degree meaning "very".

questions.full_sentence: I was late, so I ran.
questions.explanation: Use "so" as a conjunction to show a result.
Use "so" to refer back to a positive statement.
Use "so" to emphasize the adjective "hot".
Use "So" to introduce a question or a new topic.

prompt.text: He is not ___ tall as his brother.

questions.sentence_with_blank: He is not ___ tall as his brother.
questions.full_sentence: He is not so tall as his brother.

definition.ar: إدراك الصوت الصادر عن شخص أو شيء بالأذن.

questions.sentence_with_blank: He ___ a sound in the kitchen.

questions.explanation: Use "heard" for the past tense of "hear".
Use "hears" for third-person singular present.

questions.full_sentence: I have heard that story before.

Use "hearing" for the present continuous.
Use the base form "hear" after "did".
